awd_titl_txt: INFEWS/T3: Rethinking Dams: Innovative hydropower solutions to achieve sustainable food and energy production, and sustainable communities
awd_abstract_narration:
1639115
Emilio F. Moran

Hydropower dams have been an important part of worldwide energy production, but they also have resulted in substantial negative environmental and social outcomes. This project will study a new way to think about hydropower, one that looks not just at energy production as the goal, but as an integrated system that can generate ecological, economic, and societal benefits beyond electricity. The study will model scenarios to assess how hydropower technologies can be deployed in new ways, such as through enhancing production of food by applying river sediments on cropland as fertilizer, or by changing hydropower technology toward smaller dams and in-stream turbines to reduce negative outcomes on river ecology and fish productivity. Along with the training of students and postdocs, a web-based decision support system will be developed to inform stakeholders about alternative hydropower designs and locations, offer options to increase benefits to stakeholders, and serve as a lasting legacy for policy makers, scientists, and local institutions in managing their food, water and energy resources. The scenarios for redesigned hydropower will potentially transform how hydropower is viewed, replacing a top-down approach that mandates a single-minded focus on maximizing energy production with a bottom-up approach informed by the complexity interlinking the food, energy, and water systems. The project will generate innovative solutions that will improve the acceptability of hydropower development in the US, Europe, and across the world.

An estimated 3,700 major dams are currently either planned or under construction worldwide, and they will continue to play significant roles in energy production in the foreseeable future. This study's goal is to develop innovative solutions for hydropower-- not just to produce energy for the national grid, but woven into the surrounding food, water, and institutional systems. The team includes hydroengineers, hydrogeologists, climatologists, biologists and social scientists working in tandem to offer transformative solutions for hydropower development while ensuring that social and environmental benefits outweigh costs. The research teams will assess land cover change to understand deforestation risk in and around dams, and identify agricultural areas that can benefit from sediment application. Coupled hydrological and climate models, linked to land cover changes in different landscape and socio-ecological settings, including international collaborations, will identify better hydropower solutions including ways to move sediments to farms and/or locations for in-stream turbines. Institutional and governance analysis will examine the multi-tiered dimensions that intrude upon the way civil society benefits from hydropower. The project will generate innovative solutions to produce renewable energy from hydropower, increase food production, and lessen negative environmental and social impacts that have reduced the acceptability of hydropower development, in the US, Europe and across the world.

por.por_cntn:
The INFEWS project Rethinking Dams: Innovative Hydropower Solutions to achieve Sustainable Food and Energy Production, and Sustainable Communities made important scientific advances in addressing a great felt need of populations poorly served by existing energy options. The team was made up of hydroengineers, hydrogeologists, climatologists, biologists and social scientists, working together, to offer solutions.

Many alternatives were explored, and complex modeling efforts were undertaken. In the course of the project we designed an energy system that combined an in-stream turbine with photovoltaics to take advantage of the abundant streams in the study area, and the abundant sun. The turbine design took into consideration minimizing mortality of fish in the rivers, through assessment of materials and speed, and published in an engineering science journal. Modeling the hydrology of the Amazon, and the climatic conditions of the Amazon, was undertaken in order to assess the feasibility of our sollutions. We also examined the human dimensions of delivering an energy system that is more benigh than the existing large scale hydropower solutions that accounts for 67% of electricity production in Brazil. More than five papers on the social dimensions were published. 

The technical feasibility of our energy solution was presented in an article published in 2022 in PNAS Nexus showing how this two technologies' solution provides sustainable and robust energy production. Even more signficant for policy makers is the finding that fulfils our key goal, published in Nature Sustainability in 2021, that shows that the in-stream turbines alone could produce up to 63% of the energy planned to be produced by dams plannedd for the Amazon, obviating the need to keep building dams in the Amazon--thereby reducing the negative impacts on people and fisheres caused by dam construction. Complementary to this important finding, publsihed in Renewable and Sustainable Energy Reviews in 2020,is the result that the deficit in energy production could be produced by floating photovoltaics in just 10% of existing reservoirs, which in turn also complements the short fall in energy production in exisating dams during the dry season when water levels are lower and there is a significant drop in hydropower production from dams in the Amazon. These results are all the more important given other findings from our project showing how dams built to date had resulted in as much as a 37% drop in fish catches and in biodiversity losses of the same magnitude. 14 papers examined the fisheries dimensions including one in the Journal of Environmental Management in 2023.The work with communities was able to show that instead of improving livelihoods, dams had been responsible for numerous injustices such as insufficient compensation for damages experienced by households and communities, loss of social capital, and a lack of participation by people in the process of dam construction. These deficiencies are unlikely to be associated with the solutions our team developed. The proposed solutions begin by ensuring that the in-stream turbines do not have negative outcomes for the fisheries, such as fish mortality, or blockage of free flowing streams, and the proposed energy system is sized to the needs of the communities and engages their participation in the process of making it available. The project provided support for 6 PhD students and 1 Master's student, who gained valuable experience working across disciplines and becoming co-authors in the work published. All 7 degrees were completed by the time the grant ended. Several of the papers had these students as first-auhtors. A total of 36 articles were published by the participants in this project in significant journals. Participants presented numerous presentations about the work done in the project to divese audiences both in the US. and overseas. Partnerships were developed with universities overseas, that strengthened our ability to work in other countries, and mentored students both in the US and overseas in the five years of the project.
